abstract: Pledges made by 200 countries at Paris climate talks, while representing long overdue progress, still fall far short of changes needed to limit global temperature increases to safe level; negotiators have rejected scientists' recommendation to set cap on emissions and allocate them fairly among countries as politically impractical; serious consideration of 'carbon budget' would likely reveal unpleasant inequities and dire problems at heart of crisis.
lead_paragraph: Nations have pointedly declined to take up a recommendation from scientists, made several years ago, that they set a cap on total greenhouse gases.

headline.main: Paris Climate Talks Avoid Scientists’ Idea of ‘Carbon Budget’
headline.print_headline: Pledges to Cut Emissions Lag as Climate Talks Get Underway

snippet: Nations have pointedly declined to take up a recommendation from scientists, made several years ago, that they set a cap on total greenhouse gases.

keywords.value: Carbon Caps and Emissions Trading Programs
keywords.name: subject

keywords.value: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
